Least weasal is a woodland species. Use interior forest layer as an avoid mask. Amy Silvano 24jun05

Changed this from hand model to Forest/Open and Woodland/Shrubland edge with a 500 meter ecotone. MJR 18 October 2007.

references.B89KIN02NAUS: King, C. 1989. The natural history of weasels and stoats. Cornell Univ. Press, Ithaca. xviii + 253 pp.
references.B79HAM01NAUS: Hamilton, William J., Jr., and John O. Whitaker, Jr. 1979. Mammals of the eastern United States. Cornell Univ. Press, Ithaca, New York. 346 pp.
references.A75KIN01NAUS: King, C.M. 1975. The home range of the weasel (Mustela nivalis) in an English woodland. J. Animal Ecol. 44:636-668.
references.B81SCH01NAUS: Schwartz, Charles W., and Elizabeth R. Schwartz. 1981. The Wild mammals of Missouri (2nd Ed.). Univ. of Missouri Press and Missouri Conserv. Dept., Columbia, MO. 356 p.
references.B92JON01NAUS: Jones, J. K., Jr., et al. 1992. Revised checklist of North American mammals north of Mexico, 1991. Occas. Pap. Mus., Texas Tech Univ. (146):1-23.
references.A51HAL01NAUS: Hall, E.R. 1951. American Weasels. Univ. Kansas Publication, Museum Natural History, 4:1-466.
references.A94SHE01NAUS: Sheffield, S. R., and C. M. King. 1994. Mustela nivalis. Am. Soc. Mamm., Mammalian Species No. 454:1-10.
references.B85WEB01NAUS: Webster, W. D., J. F. Parnell and W. C. Biggs Jr. 1985. Mammals of the Carolinas, Virginia, and Maryland. The University of North Carolina Press, Chapel Hill, NC.
references.B93WIL01NAUS: Wilson, D. E., and D. M. Reeder (editors). 1993. Mammal Species of the World:a Taxonomic and Geographic Reference. Second Edition. Smithsonian Institution Press, Washington, DC. xviii + 1206 pp.
references.A91HAN02NAUS: Handley, C. O., Jr. 1991. Mammals. Pages 539-616 in K. Terwilliger, coordinator. Virginia's endangered species:proceedings of a symposium. McDonald and Woodward Publishing Company, Blacksburg, Virginia.
references.A70HEI01NAUS: Heidt, G.A. 1970. The least weasel Mustela nivalis Linnaeus.Developmental biology in comparison with other North American Mustela. Michigan State Univ., Publ. Mus., Biol. Ser., 4(7):227-282.
references.B81HAL01NAUS: Hall, E. R. 1981. The Mammals of North America. Second edition. 2 Volumes. John Wiley and Sons, New York, New York. 1181 p.
references.B83BAK01NAUS: Baker, Rollin H. 1983. Michigan mammals. Michigan State University Press. 642 pp.
references.B98WHI01NCGP: Whitaker, J.O. Jr. and W.J. Hamilton, Jr. 1998.  Mammals of the eastern United States. Cornell Univ. Press, Ithaca, New York. 583 pp.
references.A92FRE02NAUS: Frey, J. K. 1992. Response of a mammalian faunal element to climatic changes. J. Mamm. 73:43-50.
references.A92VAN02NAUS: van Zyll de Jong, C. G. 1992. A morphometric analysis of cranial variation in Holarctic weasels (MUSTELA NIVALIS). Zeitschrift fur Saugetierkunde 57:77-93.
references.A60GOL01NAUS: Golley, F.B. 1960. Energy dynamics of a food chain of an old-field community. Ecol. Manag. 30(2):187-206.
references.N82LEE01NAUS: Lee, D. S., L. B. Funderburg Jr., and M. K. Clark. 1982. A distributional survey of North Carolina mammals. Occasional Papers of the North Carolina Biological Survey, No. 1982-10. North Carolina State. Mus. Nat. Hist., Raleigh, North Carolina. 72 pp.
references.A74ERL01NAUS: Erlinger, S. 1974. Distribution, territoriality, and numbers of the weasel Mustela nivalis in relation to prey abundance. Oikos 25(3):308-314.
references.B74BAN01NAUS: Banfield, A.W.F. 1974. The mammals of Canada. University of Toronto Press, Toronto.
references.U75LOW01NAUS: Lowman, G. E. 1975. A survey of endangered, threatened, rare, status-undetermined, peripheral, unique mammals of thes.e. National Forests and Grasslands. USDA Forest Service Contract 38-2601. 121 pp.
